Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: Had to copy and paste as I don't know how to link [edit by admin - here's the post in the Ask about radiotherapy area] Hello Jump123  Thank you for your enquiry.   I'm sorry to hear that you have found some answers unhelpful on here.  It is certainly never our intention to trivialise people's fears and concerns.   Rest assured, there have been many projects over the years looking into skin care and radiotherapy and there have been many changes made to practice and policies.   Basically, there is no way to prevent a skin reaction during radiotherapy - just in the same way that you cannot prevent the side effects you get from chemotherapy - but they can be delayed and managed with advice  from your treatment team.   There are a lot of 'horror stories' out there regarding radiotherapy burns. The first thing to clarify is that the skin reaction is not actually a burn. Yes, we often describe it as looking a little like mild sunburn, but it is due to the skin cells below the surface of the skin being damaged and then coming to the surface as we shed skin in the normal way, not a direct burn to the skin.   Secondly, treatment techniques have come on in leaps and bounds in recent years. Once upon a  time, people did suffer painful and unsightly reactions following radiotherapy but this is not the case any more.  Treatment techniques are designed to spare as much healthy tissue as possible and to minimise side effects.   Most people having radiotherapy following a diagnosis of breast cancer will have a mild skin reaction, where the skin gets pink, it may feel warm and can sometimes itch.  Some people will get more side effects involving bright redness, itching, and very occasionally, blistering of the skin.  This tends to happen mostly underneath the breast in the fold, where skin rubs together and it can be sensitive.   This is very much a worse case scenario, and it does not happen to everyone. Management for any of these reactions is based on alleviating symptoms and providing comfort whilst waiting for the skin to heal. Most skin reactions tend to peak towards the end of the treatment course and are often at their worst in the first two weeks after treatment has completed. The majority of skin reactions have significantly improved, if not resolved, by four weeks after treatment has finished. The advice we give patients, which is based on several years of research and learning, is to regularly moisturise the skin with any moisturiser of your choosing.  There are lots of products out there that claim to be  a 'wonder cream' but actually, there is no scientific evidence to prove that any one moisturiser is better than another. Keeping the skin in good condition will prevent the radiotherapy from drying it out and thereby minimise any potential reaction.   We would also recommend wearing a more comfortable, looser bra and loose cotton clothing and avoid extremes of temperature such as hot water bottles or ice packs on the skin.   If side effects progress, your treatment team can provide a cream to help with itching, and for the worse case scenario, dressings which soothe the skin and speed up the healing process.    To answer your concern about oesophageal side effects, it is extremely rare to have any issues with the oesophagus during treatment.  Again, treatment techniques have changed so much in recent years that sensitive structures are avoided with minimal risk of any reaction.  It must be extremely scary for you facing the treatment with the worries that you have.  Your oncologist will be able to go through things with you in minute detail. You can also call the the Macmillan Support line for further help and support on 0800 808 0000 (Monday to Friday, 9am-8pm).    You have come so far and managed to get through all of the chemotherapy - a lot of people on the Breast Cancer community page will tell you that radiotherapy is much more manageable compared to chemo. There are also lots of ladies, and men, on there that will happily share their stories with you of how they found the radiotherapy not as difficult as they originally anticipated.   It won't be something that you will forget in a few weeks, but most people find their side effects have improved in this period of time.   Believe me, your treatment team DO care about your well being and management of your potential reactions.  They are there to help you. I am aware I have written a fairly lengthy reply to you Jump123, but I really hope it has helped to alleviate some of your concerns mentioned.  Please do get back in touch with me if you want further clarification of any of the information I have given you or if you have any other concerns.  My very best wishes to you,  Kate
